thread.title: 2015 field hockey preview | Cox, First Colonial nationally ranked
thread.title_full: 2015 field hockey preview | Cox, First Colonial nationally ranked | HamptonRoads.com | PilotOnline.com

author: Lee Tolliver
title: 2015 field hockey preview | Cox, First Colonial nationally ranked
text:
FIVE THINGS YOU NEED TO KNOW That didn’t last long
In 2013, South Hampton Roads teams went without a state championship for the first time since 2005. But Virginia Beach teams helped get things back on track last year by winning two of three state titles. Cox beat First Colonial 1-0 to win the Group 6A crown, while Princess Anne beat Mountain View 2-1 in the 5A championship game. On top of that, Norfolk Academy won its first private school state title with a 1-0 overtime victory over Trinity.
50-50 proposition
First Colonial senior Haley Schleicher last season became the first high school player to join the national 50-50 club, finishing with 52 goals and 52 assists. The Duke commit nearly accomplished the feat as a sophomore (47 goals, 50 assists). Schleicher is poised to become the leading career scorer in Virginia history. She is fourth all-time with 139 goals – 21 behind former Cox standout Kim Miller. Schleicher’s career total of 151 assists already is a national record.
New digs
A season after hoisting its first state title trophy, Norfolk Academy will break in a new on-campus astroturf field. Bulldogs Associate AD Chad Byler said only one other high school in the country has a similar facility that features automatic water cannons that can pump out 320 gallons of water a minute and can be controlled with a cellular phone. At Norfolk Collegiate, the Oaks also are preparing to play on a new synthetic surface after work is completed on the school’s revamped fields and lights.
Reaching goals
Cox, First Colonial and Princess Anne were three of the most dominating teams in the state. First Colonial finished with a 141-13 advantage in goals. Cox outscored opponents 118-15 and Princess Anne had a 100-10 edge. This year’s results are likely to be the same.
Some of the best
South Hampton Roads’ three powerhouses have won a combined 24 state titles since 1977. Cox leads with a state record 18 crowns. Princess Anne has four and First Colonial has two. The trio has 10 runner-up finishes combined. And just for measure, Tabb — which competed in the Group AA/A tournament before the state reclassified, and now competes in 4A — has won a combined six state titles.
___
TOP 10 TEAMS IN SOUTH HAMPTON ROADS
1. Cox
The defending Group 6A state champions are ranked third in the country in the MaxFieldHockey.com preseason poll after finishing last year at 21-2.
2. First Colonial
The defending 6A South Region and state runner-up Patriots are ranked eighth nationally after a 20-3 season — with all three losses at the hands of the Falcons.
3. Princess Anne
The Cavaliers finished last year 22-1-1, losing only to First Colonial and tying Norfolk Academy in the first three games of the season. PA is on a 21-game winning streak.
4. Hickory
Two of three Hawks’ losses last year came at the hands of Princess Anne, including a 4-0 defeat in the opening round of the Group 5A South Region tournament.
5. Norfolk Academy
The Bulldogs finished 14-5-1 last season, but still captured the school’s first VISAA state title (Div. I). The program now will have a decided homefield edge with its new astroturf complex.
6. Maury
The Commodores have been competitive since Day One and there’s no reason to think things will change. Three of the team’s six losses were to top-three teams and only by two or less goals.
7. Grassfield
The Grizzlies captured the Monitor-Merrimac title last year, but were forced to face eventual 6A state champion Cox in the first round of region play.
8. Cape Henry
The Dolphins lost their career scoring leader — Erin Scherrer, now at Duke — to graduation, but will still field a quality team.
9. Kellam
The Knights lost to Monitor-Merrimac and Peninsula power Gloucester in the first round of 5A South Region play, but return three all-conference players.
10. Lakeland
After suffering through their worst season in more than a decade, the Cavaliers return a seasoned squad with lots of experience in USA Field Hockey’s Futures Program.
Next up: Sitting just outside of the Top 10 are a few teams that easily could find their way into the lineup as the season progresses. Among them are Bishop Sullivan Catholic, Nansemond River, Great Bridge and Western Branch.
___
AROUND THE REGION
In Group 6A ...
Cox this year will feature a trio of scoring threats led by U17 National Team member Leah Crouse. She, along with Alexis Gingerich and Alex Brewer combined to score 62 goals last season. Gingerich is the leading returning scorer for the Falcons with 23. Brewer had 22. ... Jimbo Johnson takes the helm at Western Branch . Led by senior four-year starter Kennedy Johnson, Western Branch has quite a bit of private club experience. Johnson is joined by fellow seniors Riley Greenwood and Payton Grimes. ... Haley Schleicher is arguably the best player in the state, but First Colonial won’t be one-dimensional. The Patriots feature one of the top defenders in the state in ODU commit Marlee McClendon and all-state keeper Kimi Jones. And coach Beanie Schleicher — Haley’s mom — says this year’s squad has the best chemistry she’s ever coached. ... In an attempt to make another playoff run, Grassfield will ride the coat tails of returning all-conference first-teamers Kate Remley, McKinzie Tomes and Hailie Gray. ... At Oscar Smith , senior Gabby Somerville highlights a mostly youthful roster.
In Group 5A ...
Lacey Frazier anchored a Princess Anne defense that allowed only 10 goals last season. The senior goal keeper had 18 shutouts en route to a Group 5A state title. The Cavs are ranked fifth nationally. ... Cass Wagner, who played at Old Dominion as a forward/midfielder, has taken over as Maury ’s new head coach. A 2015 Monarchs graduate, she played high school hockey for Manheim Central in Lititz, Pa. She fields a quality Maury squad led by senior forward and St. Joseph’s commit Lydia Bariteau and juniors Maggie New, Grace Chavez, Becca Gaddy and Mads Crockett. ... Although only a sophomore, conference first-teamer Courtney Lynch will help lead Hickory after scoring 17 goals and dishing out 10 assists. Returning senior Kristen Ferguson had 18 goals and nine assists for the Hawks. ... Kellam has a huge freshman class that will be look to junior Natalie Belden (9 goals, 11 assists) and seniors Hannah Tammaro (15 g, 9 a) and Sophia Kottmer (3 g, 4 a) for guidance. ... With 11 returning players, Nansemond River moves to Group 5A and the PenSouth Conference after winning the Ironclad title in Group 4A. ... Salem welcomes back three seniors who saw significant playing time last season: Mallory Wolf, Kristyna Oyola and Alyssa Gore. ... Indian River – now in the Atlantic Conference – returns seniors Abby Reed and Zaria Knight and junior Kayla Maret.
In Group 4A ...
Don’t be surprised if Deep Creek makes some noise this season. The Hornets have several players who have been playing on some of the state’s top club teams. Senior defenders Katie Dezern and Macayla Gillis are joined by keeper Brooke Norwood-Vanzie and forward Brianna Sawyer. ... At Great Bridge , Reyton Tollaksen led the team in scoring last season as a freshman and earned first-team all-conference honors.
In Group 3A ...
Despite a 9-10 season, coaches recognized the talent of Lakeland senior Stasha Waterfield and awarded her a second-team all-state honor.
In private schools ...
After graduating its all-time leading scorer, Cape Henry was hoping to lean on the stick of U-17 National Team member Charlotte DeVries. But the rising freshman moved to Pennsylvania with her family. The Dolphins will still be competitive, with freshman Alexandra Land leading the way. Senior Virginia Apperson looks to finally step out of the shadows. ... Norfolk Academy is ranked sixth in the Mid-Atlantic Region behind Cox (1), First Colonial (2) and Princess Anne (5) in the MaxFieldHockey.com preseason regional rankings. The Bulldogs midfielders Grace Marshall, Greer Gill and Halle Gill along with forward Riley Fulmer, a member of the U.S. National Indoor team. ... Veteran Bishop Sullivan Catholic coach Beth Kennehan (10 years) is fielding the youngest team she’s ever coached, which could make it tough to break into the TCIS top two. She does have a senior duo in Jordan Quigley and Julia Mooney.
___
RECLASSIFICATION
Another round of realignment by the Virginia High School League has shuffled area teams for the 2015-16 school year. For the first time, Hampton Roads public schools will be spread across four classifications – Group 6A, Group 5A, Group 4A and Group 3A.
Four teams move down in classification: Booker T. Washington, Norcom, Lakeland and Phoebus all move to Group 3A, while Great Bridge heads to Group 4A.
Kellam, meanwhile, has moved up to Group 6A and Nansemond River to Group 5A.
A look at the new conference alignment:
Group 6A
Coastal Conference: Bayside, Cox, First Colonial, Kellam, Landstown, Ocean Lakes, Tallwood.
Monitor-Merrimac Conference: Granby, Grassfield, Oscar Smith, Western Branch, Woodside.
Group 5A
Atlantic Conference: Green Run, Hickory, Indian River, Kempsville, Maury, Norview, Princess Anne, Salem.
PenSouth Conference: Bethel, Gloucester, Hampton, Kecoughtan, Menchville, Nansemond River, Warwick.
Group 4A
Conference 17: Churchland, Deep Creek, Great Bridge, King’s Fork, Lake Taylor, Wilson.
Ironclad Conference: Denbigh, Grafton, Heritage, Jamestown, Lafayette, Smithfield.
Group 3A
Conference 27: Booker T. Washington, Lakeland, Norcom, Phoebus, Tabb, York.
